consolidation_metadata.enhancement_level: Comprehensive goals consolidation from multiple archival sources with enhanced Ayakulik River goals

data_quality.goal_accuracy: Extracted from official ADF&G documentation and management plans
data_quality.source_attribution: All goals have documented sources with ADF&G references
data_quality.completeness: Goals available for locations with established management plans
data_quality.verification_status: Goals extracted from authoritative ADF&G sources

goal_types.SEG: Sustainable Escapement Goal - Long-term population sustainability target
goal_types.BEG: Biological Escapement Goal - Biological minimum for population health
goal_types.OSM: Optimal Sustaining Model - Population optimization target
goal_types.Inriver: Inriver Management Target - Fishery management within river
goal_types.Harvest: Harvest Target - Commercial/sport fishing harvest goals
goal_types.Production: Production Goal - Hatchery or enhancement targets

goals.description: Historical research weir, important for long-term data. Sockeye escapement monitoring for research purposes.

1_420.management_context: Research station with long-term monitoring data
1_420.notes: Location marked as dormant - verify current status

goals.description: Buskin weir for sockeye escapement is located at the outlet of the Buskin Lake between May 25 thru August 15. A second weir is installed down river on August 15th to just above bridge #2, where it remains until September 30 to enumerate coho salmon.

6_420.management_context: Dual weir system for sockeye and coho monitoring
6_420.notes: Primary focus on sockeye with secondary coho monitoring

goals.description: Buskin weir for sockeye escapement is located at the outlet of the Buskin Lake between May 25 thru August 15. A second weir is installed down river on August 15th to just above bridge #2, where it remains until September 30 to enumerate coho salmon.

6_430.management_context: Secondary monitoring species with dedicated weir
6_430.notes: Coho monitoring occurs after sockeye season ends

goals.description: Chinook salmon escapement has been monitored via weirs in the Anchor River since 2003. Escapements have ranged from a low of 2,338 in 2023, to a high of 12,016 in 2004. The Chinook salmon run to the Anchor River begins in mid-May and lasts through early August. Historically, 50% of the Chinook salmon run had passed the weir by June 10, but later run timing in recent years has pushed the 50% date to the third week in June to early July.

9_410.management_context: Long-term monitoring with established escapement goals
9_410.notes: Run timing has shifted later in recent years

goals.description: Deep Creek Chinook salmon monitoring with established sustainable escapement goals for population management.

17_410.management_context: Established Chinook monitoring with SEG targets

goals.description: Dog Salmon weir is just upstream from the mouth of the Dog Salmon River which drains into Olga Bay on the south end of Kodiak Island. A tributary of this stream drains Frazer Lake. This system has an introduced sockeye run. The sockeye run was introduced in 1953 followed with the installation of a fish ladder at just downstream from the lake outlet in 1962 to allow the fish to utilize Frazer Lake.
goals.source: Official ADFG Fish Counts Tool - Dog Salmon River

27_420.management_context: Weir monitoring with biological escapement goals
27_420.notes: Introduced sockeye run with established escapement goals

goals.description: Upper station monitoring for Olga Creek sockeye salmon with established biological escapement goals.

29_420.management_context: Upper station monitoring with BEG targets
29_420.notes: Part of Olga Creek monitoring system

goals.description: Situk River Chinook salmon monitoring with established biological escapement goals for population health.

32_410.management_context: Established Chinook monitoring with BEG targets

goals.description: The Sonar on the Copper River is located at the outlet of Miles Lake, about 70 miles from the Chitina dipnet fishery. It takes approximately 2 weeks for salmon to travel this distance, but this is highly variable depending on the water level. The current escapement goal for Sockeye is 360,000 to 750,000.
goals.source: Official ADFG Fish Counts Tool - Copper River (Miles Lake)

23_420.management_context: Sonar monitoring with sustainable escapement goals

chinook.description: Biological escapement goal for Chinook salmon at Ayakulik River weir

25_410.management_context: Weir monitoring with biological escapement goals for population health
25_410.notes: Biological goals for population health. Chinook salmon run begins mid-May and lasts through early August. Historically, 50% of the Chinook salmon run had passed the weir by June 10, but later run timing in recent years has pushed the 50% date to the third week in June to early July.
25_410.verification_method: Direct from official ADFG website screenshot

goals.description: Karluk River sockeye salmon monitoring with established sustainable escapement goals for long-term population management.

33_420.management_context: Established sockeye monitoring with SEG targets

goals.description: The DIDSON (sonar) is used to estimate passage of late-run sockeye salmon at river mile 19 of the Kenai River. The department manages for a sustainable escapement goal (SEG) and inriver management targets set by the Alaska Board of Fisheries. These inriver goals vary year to year depending on the estimated run size in the Kenai River.
goals.source: Official ADFG Fish Counts Tool - Kenai River (Late-Run Sockeye)

40_420.management_context: Primary late-run sockeye monitoring with dual goal system
40_420.notes: Dual goal system: SEG for sustainability, inriver for fishery management. Inriver goals vary annually based on estimated run size.

goals.description: Gulkana River Chinook salmon monitoring with established sustainable escapement goals for population management.

51_410.management_context: Established Chinook monitoring with SEG targets
51_410.notes: Sustainable goals for Interior Chinook population

goals.description: Pasagshak weir for sockeye escapement is located approximately a quarter mile below outlet of the Lake Rose Tead. Fish are counted through the weir between June 10 and August 15th. The escapement goal for Sockeye is a minimum threshold.

60_420.management_context: Weir-based monitoring with minimum threshold goals
60_420.notes: Minimum threshold goal rather than range

goals.description: The Nushagak River sonar site is located about 37 miles upstream of Nushagak Bay on the Nushagak River. In 2022, the Division of Commercial Fisheries is modifying the methodology on how downstream fish are accounted for at the Nushagak River sonar site.
goals.source: Official ADFG Fish Counts Tool - Nushagak River

41_410.management_context: Sonar monitoring with sustainable escapement and inriver goals
41_410.notes: Dual goal system: SEG for sustainability, inriver for fishery management

24_420.management_context: Sonar monitoring with biological and optimal escapement goals
24_420.notes: Dual goal system: BEG for population health, OEG for optimization

goals.description: The Chignik River weir is located about 5 km upstream from Chignik Lagoon. The weir is approximately 122 m in width, ranging from 0.6 m to 3.5 m in depth. Operated by the Division of Commercial Fisheries.
goals.source: Official ADFG Fish Counts Tool - Chignik River

23_410.management_context: Weir monitoring with biological escapement goals

sockeye.description: Sustainable escapement goal for sockeye salmon at Ayakulik River weir

25_420.management_context: Weir monitoring with sustainable escapement goals for long-term population management
25_420.notes: Sustainable escapement goal for sockeye salmon. Ayakulik River is a major producer of sockeye salmon. The weir is operated by the Division of Commercial Fisheries and is located on the southwest end of Kodiak Island. Besides its commercial importance, it has a high level of sport fishing use.
25_420.verification_method: Direct from official ADFG website screenshot

data_sources.verification_status: Goals verified from official ADFG website as of 2025-08-18

notes.goal_interpretation: Goals represent official ADF&G management targets for fish population sustainability and fishery management
notes.data_limitations: Not all locations have established goals; goals may be updated with management plan revisions
notes.usage_guidelines: Use goals for management context and population health assessment; verify current status with ADF&G
notes.future_enhancements: Additional goals may be available in PDF documents and management plan updates
